Award.AwardTitle: NSF Support of Student Travel Grants to APS-DAMOP 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
The support of students through this award makes a substantial contribution to the education and training of future scientists. Students who graduate with a background in atomic, molecular, and optical physics acquire a broad range of knowledge and skills that enable them to contribute to progress in many areas of science and technology.

This award provides travel support for student participation in the 47th Annual Meeting of the American Physical Society Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics (APS-DAMOP). Support is provided only for US students (students enrolled in US universities). This Conference has grown in recent years and attracts over one-thousand participants. Covering all the major areas of atomic, molecular and optical physics, this conference series is of outstanding importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States. This Conference offers an opportunity for students to present their research results and to interact with senior scientists primarily from the United States, but also the broader international community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF supported 20 students to attend the 47th Annual Meeting of the American Physical Society Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics (APS-DAMOP) held May 23-27, 2016 at the Rhode Island Convention Center, in Providence, RI. The DAMOP Conference has grown in recent years and attracts over one thousand participants. The Conference is an official meeting of the American Physical Society with a total budget exceeding $300,000. Support is needed to ensure the participation of a large and diverse group of researchers, and to help foster the interchange of scientific information among young scientists. Because of its influence on the productivity and up-to-date awareness of individual investigators, this conference series is of outstanding importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical physics in the United States.

Because of its influence on the productivity and up-to-date awareness of individual investigators, this conference series is of outstanding importance to the vitality of atomic, molecular, and optical (AMO) physics in the United States.  It is particularly important that younger members of our AMO community be able to attend and learn about the cutting-edge work occurring throughout the community, fostering both intellectual development in the field and broader impacts in terms of networking, visibility, and interdisciplinary connection.  Funds for twenty student travel awards was provided by NSF.
